did.unittitle: Papers of Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben
did.abstract: The collection includes correspondence, orders, memoranda, petitions, indentures, and writings on military topics by Baron von Steuben during his tenure as an officer of the American army, as well as material relating to his estate and memorials.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben (1730-1794) served as inspector general of the Continental army and is credited with introducing to it European military concepts that began its transformation into a truly professional military establishment.

chronitem.event: Serves as staff officer in the Prussian military during the Seven Years' War.
Named chamberlain for Prince Joseph Friedrich Wilhelm of Hohenzollern-Hechige, in southern Germany.
In June, after rumors of homosexual activity force him to resign, visits Paris to seek a position in the French army or the army of the United States through their representatives there.

Although initially discouraged by Benjamin Franklin and Silas Deane because he spoke only French and German, receives letters of introduction to George Washington and Robert Morris predicated on his serving in the Continental army only as a volunteer.
Arrives at Valley Forge to serve under Washington, having informed Congress of his desire for paid service after an initial volunteer trial period, with which request Washington concurs.
Begins tenure as inspector general, drilling troops according to established European military precepts.

Writes "Regulations for the Order and Discipline of the Troops of the United States," which becomes a fundamental guide for the Continental army and remains in active use through the War of 1812, being published in over 70 editions.
Senior military officer in charge of troop and supply mobilization in Virginia.
Replaced by Marquis de Lafayette as commander in Virginia.
Continues to serve as Washington's inspector general, and is active in improving discipline and streamlining administration in the army.
Assists in formulating plans for the postwar American military.
Lives in New York City under increasing burden of debt.
Successfully applies to Congress for a military pension.
Lives at his farm near Utica, New York, on land given to him by the state in 1786.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The physical collection consists of 15 boxes of correspondence and writings (1 oversize) from 1778 to 1851 and 6 volumes. Many documents are in French.

The bulk of the correspondence (1779-1781) concerns Steuben's efforts to reorganize the Continental Army and to make Virginia a base of General Nathaniel Greene's army during Steuben's command of forces there. They relate to matters including the preparation and distribution of his Regulations, reactions to and questions about his work, appointment of inspectors, supply needs, organization and administration of army and militia units, enemy movements and strength, and British forces in Virgina, among other topics.

Steuben's correspondents include Col. Jean Baptiste Ternant, Col. William Davies, the Board of War, M. de Franey, Chevalier de la Luzerne, Gen. Nathanael Greene, Gov. Thomas Jefferson, Col. Edward Carrington, Col. George Gibson, Gen. Thomas Nelson, Gen. George Weedon, Gen. Peter Muhlenberg, Louis de Pontiere, Gen. Robert Lawson, Gen. Isaac Gregory, Col. J. Junis, Gen. Mordecai Gist, Maj. Buller Claiborne, Capt. John Pryor, Capt. William North, Col. Benjamin Walker, and Gen. Benjamin Lincoln.
The correspondence from 1778 to 1789 has been microfilmed on reels 1, 2, and 3 (which correspond to boxes 1-3) and will be presented in this format.

The volumes include a letter book dealing with official military matters and including correspondence addressed to the War Board, George Washington, and other officers (1780 January - 1781 January); "Regulations pour la cavalerie ou corps legionaire [sic]" (partly in English), discussing the reorganization of the Continental Army's cavalry units in 1780-1781; "Thoughts on a national militia", containing several miscellaneous documents in French and English discussing the establishment of a peacetime army (ca. 1784); "Thoughts on the growth of the western territory," discussing political relations with Spain and Britain, and proposing settlements in Spanish Louisiana (ca. 1788); and a journal, in French, describing work, relations with tenants, and projected improvements on his farm in Oneida County, New York (1790-1792).
These five volumes have been microfilmed on reel 4 (which corresponds to box 4) and will be presented in this format.
The volume "The Exercise of Troops" (in French), undated but bound within covers that are pages of a 1778 newspaper, has not been microfilmed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The physical collection is arranged in 15 boxes (1 oversize) and six bound volumes. The microfilm is arranged by reel number.
